Package com.phunware.locationmessaging.log

The Logger.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    Logger
    A Logger handles log messages and errors at different log levels.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    CompositeLogger
    Support delegating log messages to a collection of child Loggers.
    FileLogger
    Writes log messages as text to a file.
    Logging
    API for sending log output.
    LogLogger
    Writes log messages to Android's logcat.
    VoidLogger
    This is a no-op log implementation.

Package com.phunware.locationmessaging.log Description

The Logger.

The Logger interface provides all of the standard logging levels, but allows developers to create their own implementation capable of things like sending message to a log aggregator, or logging to a file.

  • v(String tag, String message, Throwable t);
  • i(String tag, String message, Throwable t);
  • d(String tag, String message, Throwable t);
  • w(String tag, String message, Throwable t);
  • e(String tag, String message, Throwable t);
  • wtf(String tag, String message, Throwable t);

Built in Loggers

There will be several standard Log implementations that users can choose from, or they can create their own.
  • VoidLogger is a no-op log implementation. This can be used in production environments to drop all log messages.
  • FileLogger writes log messages as text to a file. This can support log rotation based on size or time, and will need to write to the file on a background thread so as not to hinder performance. This will be on by default in dev.
  • LogLogger writes log messages to Android's logcat. This will be on by default in dev.
  • CompositeLogger will support delegating log messages to a collection of child log messages. This will be used to support both FileLogger and LogLogger in dev.

Configuration

Log implementations can be included via the LocationMessaging.Builder, and will default to VoidLogger in production, and CompositeLogger, with FileLogger and LogLogger in development. 

 public class MyApplication extends Application {
   @Override public void onCreate() {
     super.onCreate();

     LocationMessaging.builder()
         .addLogger(new FileLogger(this))
         .addLogger(new MyServerLogger())
         ...
         .build();
   }
 }
